comment: CLSI use R >= (mic) or R<= (zone) whereas EUCAST use R>value. Hence the use of decimal places to keep scripts valid with 'R > value'.

reference: CLSI, 2018. M100 - Performance Standards for Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing, 28th Edition.
comment: CLSI use R >= (mic) or R<= (zone) whereas EUCAST use R>value. Hence the use of decimal places to keep scripts valid with 'R > value'.
comment2: BSAC, 2012. Table 6. MIC and zone diameter breakpoints for Enterobacteriaceae (including Salmonella and Shigella spp.) v11. -- Claims Salmonella spp. Should be reported as resistant to Am, Tob, Gentamicin (Aminoglycosides) as they are inactive invivo.
comment3: Streptomycin not administered clinically in UK (EUCAST) or US (CLSI), so no cbps available for MIC. Used McDermot 2016 breakpoint of >= 64ug/ml.
